speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: We're also very well-positioned to capture new wealth, just think about what Citi does in terms of our footprint, our capabilities really supports the wealth creation, from the Commercial Bank, our Investment Banking side, Markets, obviously, Services supporting it, too. These are all great feeders for us to strengthen wealth relationships with our clients.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: So we brought in Andy. Andy greatly sharpened the focus on the investment business, this is where we see the big upside. He's been building a differentiated value proposition around wealth creation.  He’s been leveraging a lot of the leading capital market capabilities, the different relationships we have with PE firms, asset managers around the world. Get a great platform in place and importantly, improving our client experience, again, particularly around investments, asset allocation, performance, et cetera.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: What I have also got to love is the surgical approach that he's taking to the expense base and driving productivity, something that we're doing across the firm. I'm also excited by the talent he's bringing, in the market leaders like Kate Moore and Keith Glenfield in the investment space.  And we've made a lot of investments in training and building this investment culture that we didn't have before.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: So to your point, the proof points are working. Q4 revenue up 20%, operating margin at 21% on its way to 25% to 30%, 10% RoTCE on its way to 15% to 20%. These last few quarters, you've just seen us on that march. And the number I'm most excited by, net new investment asset inflow of $42 billion, up 40% year-over-year. The strategy is working. We're going to be a leader in wealth, the growth opportunities, Asia U.S., Middle East, all the places where we are with our existing clients and the new wealth generators of the future.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: And if I can draw a parallel to the Banking segment with the RoTCE is about 5% to 6% last few quarters. There you brought in Vis Raghavan from JPMorgan. Just give us a sense of could we see a similar trajectory in that business over the next 12 months and where the opportunities are to improve that ROE?
speaker: EBRAHIM POONAWALA
source:
EBRAHIM POONAWALA (Analyst)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: Yes. I think absolutely, a strong performance, the strategy we have in place is delivering nicely. So if you look at the revenues, the investment banking fees, positive operating leverage all through the year and gaining share. All three products gaining share in all three in all of the geographies we're in, I'm really excited and happy to see the health care and technology, two areas that we've been investing heavily behind. And you're also seeing us playing a leading role in some of the key transactions, the biggest transactions last year. Mars Kellanova, single adviser, big role in Boeing, and then just this week, the J&J acquisition of Intracellular. So the deals that matter, this is where you're seeing Citi playing a leading role in.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: So when Vis joined, the mandate, a bit similar to Andy, becoming a top three investment bank, deliver the full potential of One Citi to our clients. So we've got a lot of upside there, instilling some more discipline in capital allocation, client coverage, some of the cross-firm linkages. We're getting a lot more from our people. We've been bringing in some great new talent we've also been cutting some of the unproductive spend.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 10

text: I think what you can see is we're just on a path of systematically growing our wallet. We'll be improving our operating margin, generating higher returns. That should be your expectation over the next couple of years of what you'll see from us. And as we head into great environment in 2025 that should be pretty conducive for a lot of client activity. I'm very confident we're well positioned. We've got the groundwork done to take advantage of it.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Ebrahim, I thought I heard you say RoTCE of 5%. It's actually 7% for the full year for Banking and on its way to the target that we've set of mid-teens for our Banking business.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Our next question comes from the line of Erika Najarian with UBS. Your line is now open, please go ahead.
speaker: OPERATOR
source:
OPERATOR (Other)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Thank you. Hate to ask the umpteenth question on the buyback, but clearly, the way the stock is reacting today, the buyback is very important to your shareholders. I guess my first question, if I could have the two questions, is it's very clear that you want to return capital to shareholders. It's very clear that you have excess capital. It's very clear that your PPNR trajectory is positive. And so what are the specific mile markers that that Citi needs to see in order to increase that pacing from that $1.5 billion a quarter to something is more suggestive of a pace that that would be in line with that $20 billion authorization? And I know that's been asked of you already, but is it the consent order? Is it the stress test? We had some news over the holidays that were positive for the sector. Like what are those specific mile markers? I mean you're doing it on the PPNR side, right? Like what do you need to see to have even more confidence, again, like leaning into Betsy’s words, to go all in on the buyback?
speaker: ERIKA NAJARIAN
source:
ERIKA NAJARIAN (Analyst)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Yes. So thank you for the question. Let me make clear a couple of things. So one, and I've said this already, so I apologize for repeating myself, but one, our target for CET1 is 13.1%, and so what you're going to see over the course of the year is us managing down to that target? That's kind of one point.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: The second point I want to be clear is that it's not the consent order. That's not something that that is impacting the capital actions and decisions that we take. We obviously forecast out the performance. As I've said, Jane has said already, we see very strong continued earnings momentum, managing towards a 13.1% CET1 ratio. And you'll see the buyback trajectory reflect getting down to that CET1.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: The one thing I will mention, and you mentioned already is that we obviously have another CCAR process, stress test that we will go through. And none of us can predict kind of what's on the other side of that from an SCB point of view, but that will be an important factor as we get through the first half of the year and into the second half of the year in terms of kind of the level of buybacks that we will be taking on a quarter-by-quarter basis.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: So I hope that helped. There are no artificial constraints, so to speak, that are in place. This is us planning and forecasting the performance of the franchise ensuring they can fuel high-returning growth opportunities so that we're building a sustainable franchise, looking at the capital requirements that we have and the management buffer that we put in place and therefore, taking that excess capacity and putting it towards buybacks, but with an eye towards the regulatory environment that we're in, and what I mean by that are the capital requirements that come out of the annual stress testing process that's run. So that's the basics of it as we sit here today.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: Got it. And just my second question, as we think about 2026. And again, I don't want to put words in your mouth because clearly, it's very critical in terms of your targets and hitting them. So you targeted less than $53 billion. Is it fair to assume like Jim was asking that $51 billion to $53 billion is not the target, but it's less than $53 billion? But to that end, I mean just taking a step back, I think, Jane, you said something very important in that want to get to the returns in a sustainable way. And clearly, your shareholders are scarred by previous management when the returns went up to double digits and went back tumbling down and wasn't sustainable. And should we just really think of this as, look, like it takes a while to turn around a money center bank and 2026 may have been the target in 2022, but we're going to get there in 2027, 2028 anyway, and just doing this in a sustainable way, and we're not robbing the bank of investments.
speaker: ERIKA NAJARIAN
source:
ERIKA NAJARIAN (Analyst)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 11

text: I guess I'm just trying to think about everybody is super focused on what you had said previously, now you have different targets, but is it just really like, look, it just takes longer, we'll get there, but just takes longer. And maybe just an addendum to that, how should we expect Banamex to impact that 10% to 11% RoTCE in terms of the immediate impact after IPO and then after you deploy that excess capital that you get back?
speaker: ERIKA NAJARIAN
source:
ERIKA NAJARIAN (Analyst)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Erika, we chose the words very carefully to say that 2026 is a way point, it's not the destination. And when I'm looking at it, I'm looking out to 2027, 2028, what is the bank we want to be in terms of our strategy, our performance, our culture, all those different dimensions. And we just relentlessly keep going down that path, but we're going to take the right and responsible decisions as we go down it. So our potential is for more than our medium-term target RoTCE, the potential of the bank and the journey that we're on is to improve our returns beyond there, for sure.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: And then you asked a question about Banamex. So, on that front, look, we had a singular focus on the separation of two banks, that was an enormous body of work because we had to put up Mexico's eighth largest Bank de Novo in a very short period of time. It got done December 1, that was over 100 regulatory approvals to get that done. Now we have turned our full attention to the IPO. We're getting ready to be able to IPO as soon we can. But given market conditions and given regulatory approvals, it's possible this could go into 2026, but we're doing everything in our control to be ready as soon as possible. We are not the right owner of the bank. We are committed to the simplification of Citi. We will follow a responsible process here.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: And just in terms of the impact and the timing that Jane referenced, just keep in in mind that the financial impact of exiting Banamex comes two forms. One is the gain or loss on sale and two is the risk-weighted asset release. The gain or loss on sale will run through the P&L at deconsolidation, so that's the point where we've gotten, or we've IPO-ed more than the 50%. And the ultimate benefit will be driven by the RWA release when we fully divest our stake. And so hopefully, that helps, but it's not until we’ve deconsolidated that we see that P&L impact and the CTA and other things like that kind of flow through the P&L for Banamex.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Our next question will come from Gerard Cassidy with RBC Capital Markets. Your line is now open, please go ahead.
speaker: OPERATOR
source:
OPERATOR (Other)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Jane, I'll pass on the haggis, but I'll take you up on the whiskey.
speaker: GERARD CASSIDY
source:
GERARD CASSIDY (Analyst)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: I didn't say I was buying just to be clear.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: Okay, I got it. Our expense report on this end. Anyway, just following up, Mark, on your comments about the IPO with Banamex. Can you guys remind us, or refresh our memories, on when the IPO process starts, once it goes public, what percentage ownership do you guys expect to have? And second, have you given us any color on whether you expect to report a gain on this transaction or a loss as you just referenced, that will go through the P&L?
speaker: GERARD CASSIDY
source:
GERARD CASSIDY (Analyst)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: We haven't given any sense for the exact timing of that. As you know, this is a process. And so Jane just spoke to the timing of that process, the first step, having been completed on December 1 with the separation, we are now obviously gearing up and readying ourselves for the IPO.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: There'll obviously be important filings associated with that given our intent to dual list, there will be regulatory approvals that are required kind of as we make headway with potential investors as part of the IPO process. And so there are a series of IPO steps that we will need to take over the course of the year in order to continue to ready ourselves and there are things that we don't control. Like as Jane mentioned, the regulatory approval process and timing for that as well as the market conditions.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 12

text: And so all of those factors are important. And then how the IPO occurs in terms of percentage that is taken on at that first tranche versus follow-on tranches are important factors on when we get to deconsolidation. And so I haven't given you an exact timing on that but you can envision kind of 15% tranches that happen over kind of a 12-, 18-month, 24-month period. And then obviously reaching a point of deconsolidation at which point that currency translation adjustment starts to flow through the P&L. There's no material impact on capital, but it does flow through the P&L. And then ultimately, we exit 100% over the course of time.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: So I'm sorry, I'm not giving you precise dates and percentages. And part of that is because we are obviously on the front end of not only readying ourselves but considering alternative IPO structures and potential investors/shareholders as part of that process.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: Well, I appreciate the insights. And then as a follow-up question, and I really don't mean this as a ‘what have you done for me lately?’ type of question because you guys have made so much progress in what you're doing in your strategic changes here. But can you talk about the U.S. Personal Banking, many of your questions today is about the RoTCE consolidated and how you can improve that, and this business has a very low RoTCE as you guys know, below your cost of capital. And structurally, when you look at it, if you look at the loans at the end of period just over $220 billion, your deposits about $90 billion, which is quite a bit different than your peers who have much higher ROEs. So how do you approach this business? And again, I know you've been very busy divesting a lot of the businesses that are not important, but it seems to me that this is a giant hurdle that you guys have to approach at some point in the near future.
speaker: GERARD CASSIDY
source:
GERARD CASSIDY (Analyst)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: Let me just chat a bit through this. So what’s the path to the higher returns in U.S. Personal Banking, it’s coming from top line revenue growth, improved expense base and also a lot more normalized credit environment, and that gets us to the mid- to high-teen returns in the medium term. I think we feel very confident and comfortable in that. You're seeing the proof points I talked about Banking, Wealth earlier, we’ve had another good quarter of revenue growth, had the ninth consecutive quarter of positive operating leverage. So I think you should be getting some comfort around that.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: What's going to drive that growth? Co-brands, we just extended with American to be their sole issuer. It's going to give exciting benefits to the American Airlines and the Citi cardholders. And it will be beneficial for both our growth and our returns. In the proprietary front, we're investing. There's a lot of investment in innovation to drive growth. The refreshed Strata Premier Card, we've been enhancing the reward offerings and you're seeing us often now #1 in recognitions and awards around that area.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: Retail Services being forensically focused on improving the partnership economics and driving top line growth. And then Retail Banking, there we're driving primary checking growth, we’ve put in simplified banking, so we get a much more streamlined customer proposition that's driving more of a relationship-based banking approach as opposed to a transactional one.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: Importantly as well, the Retail Bank has been feeding our Wealth business. I think you heard me earlier talking about that almost $3 trillion “off us” investment opportunity that we have from the retail banking customer base. We transferred $17 billion of deposits from USPB to Wealth, so you've got to take that, those dynamics into account. So I hope you're taking from me, I feel confident in our ability to get to the medium-term targets we set for the business of mid- to high-teens. I feel comfortable about the growth trajectory that we've got based off the innovations we're putting through and the changes. And good expense discipline and a better credit environment. So when you look at the mix of our business, I think you'll see us performing nicely here.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: Our next question comes from the line of Matt O'Connor with Deutsche Bank. Your line is now open, please go ahead.
speaker: OPERATOR
source:
OPERATOR (Other)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: Hi, I just want to follow up on Page 9 where you break out the technology and Transformation investment spend. And sorry if I missed this, but did you talk about the pace of those two levels in your 2025 and 2026 expense guidance? I know directionally, you said it's going up. But did you give a magnitude?
speaker: MATT O’CONNOR
source:
MATT O’CONNOR (Analyst)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: I did not. Obviously, for both technology and Transformation those are areas that we are going to continue to invest in for all the reasons that we've mentioned. They obviously contribute to the number in 2025 being slightly down from the $53.8 billion, but they also represent, as I mentioned, what we believe is required to kind of get the work done that we need to get done. And so those numbers will increase.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: There are lots of puts and takes, as you know, through an annual expense forecast, right, including, as you would expect, we've got volume, we’ve got revenue growth here that's going to come with volume growth. Volume, incentive comp, there's merit increases that go with that. And then we also have a series of productivity actions that are playing through to offset those headwinds, whether it be the additional carryover from the org simplification and full year impact of that, or some of the Legacy/stranded coming down.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 13

text: And so there are puts and takes, but Transformation and technology specifically, we are continuing to invest in, in order to achieve what we need to get done here and also ensure the businesses have what they need to drive sustainable growth going forward.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: And I guess, like how do you know that the recent increase that you're modeling internally in these areas, how do you know you're spending enough and in the right ways to address your goals in the Transformation and also satisfy the regulatory requirements?
speaker: MATT O’CONNOR
source:
MATT O’CONNOR (Analyst)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: Well, if I jump in, I feel very confident indeed that we know what we need to do. We know what we need to be spending on. Through the annual planning process that that concluded last month, it was clear we did need to invest more. We increased the scope of some of the work on the data front. We brought some other work forward. We looked at what we needed to do on the technology front and some of the critical investments. So this is pretty forensic and when we're looking at Transformation, we're looking at technology, we know what our target states need to be, and we know what we need to do to get there and the outcomes we need to be delivering.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: So we've got our arms around this, and I think you're hearing that confidence from us around what we need to do. We know the investments we need to make. You know what the outcomes and the benefits for shareholders and the regulatory side need to be.
speaker: JANE FRASER
source:
JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: Our next question comes from the line of Saul Martinez with HSBC. Your line is now open, please go ahead.
speaker: OPERATOR
source:
OPERATOR (Other)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: Mark, the NII ex-Markets outlook, if I just take the fourth quarter and annualize that, I get to something in the neighborhood of, I think, around $47.4 billion, $47.5 billion which is above the full year 2024 level. I'm not sure exactly what “up modestly” means, if that's 1%, 3%, 4%, but, and correct me if you think I’m wrong, but it seems like maybe there's a little bit of conservatism built in? If you can just comment on how you think, and how we should think about the quarterly trajectory of NI ex-Markets? Obviously, there's a day count issue in 1Q, but maybe how do you think through like, how we should expect that NII to evolve over the course of the year?
speaker: SAUL MARTINEZ
source:
SAUL MARTINEZ (Analyst)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: I mean, why don't I just kind of cut to the chase on it a little bit, Saul, in the sense that, “up modestly”, call it a couple of percentage points, 2 to 3 percentage points or so, right, in terms of how I think about it. And I think I've taken, I’ve gone through kind of the tailwinds and headwinds, so I won't kind of take you through that again. But I think the important takeaway should be that we're going to see continued momentum across the franchise driven by loan growth in the Branded Card side of the business and continued deposit momentum, particularly operating deposits in Services. And we're going to do everything that we always do around the management of pricing, and we'll get a benefit from how we've been managing our investment portfolio as those things mature. The combination of those efforts will offset, more than offset some of the headwinds that you'd expect in a declining rate environment, and modestly is, call it, 2% to 3%.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: Okay. Fair enough. And then on the expense outlook getting to below $53 billion in 2026, I know that's consistent with what you've said in the past, does imply a pretty sharp reduction in 2026, especially in light of continued revenue growth, it's pretty material operating leverage. Just I mean, how much benefit do you get from a more normalized severance? In other words, how much are we thinking about severance coming down? What's sort of the impact or how to think about the Legacy, stranded costs coming down? Just maybe a little bit more meat on the bone in terms of how much these items will benefit 2026 versus 2025?
speaker: SAUL MARTINEZ
source:
SAUL MARTINEZ (Analyst)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: Look, a couple of things. As I look at our severance costs, which, as I mentioned, has been running high, it was $700 million, we're forecasting $600 million in 2025. I think kind of normal through the cycle is probably, call it, $300 million or so. And so that gives you some sense for that.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 14

text: I think the other thing is, if you look at the other page, and again, there are a number of drivers or levers that we intend to pull to bring that down. But in the All Other page where you look to the right, we show wind-downs and what's remaining in terms of Legacy Franchise. If you add those numbers together, $1.9 billion or so of expenses and think about a subset of that being stranded. And we're going to continue to focus on how do we bring down stranded costs over the next couple of years.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 15

text: So those are two important factors or contributors to the decline from the slightly lower than $53.8 billion to the $53 billion. There are additional productivity saves from prior investments that we've made. But those are important factors. And then as we look at the Transformation spend, that will continue to, or start to pay dividends or help to bring down costs as well. So you've got really those four variables that contribute to us bringing that number down. And as Jane has mentioned, we're going to even post 2026, continue to bring, or drive out more inefficiencies around the organization to fund required investments for the business growth and all with a continued focus on getting to less than 60% as we exit 2026, less than 60% operating efficiency.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 15

text: Our final question will come from the line of Mike Mayo with Wells Fargo. Your line is now open, please go ahead.
speaker: OPERATOR
source:
OPERATOR (Other)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 15

text: Hi, this is your first full year of having the five line of business structure. So, Mark, do you still have the same line of business targets that you had last year? And Jane, with all the, it must have been a degree of hell to organize this way, get rid of your two intercompany holding companies, eliminate five layers of management, expand span of control and you guys went through a lot last year. And I'm just wondering, is the worst over in terms of that kind of reorganization internally and the culture and the sentiment and how you see that continuing? But first, the concrete question about the targets, please.
speaker: MIKE MAYO
source:
MIKE MAYO (Analyst)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 15

text: So I guess I'll start first. So in terms of the targets, look, we set the targets across each of the lines of business for the medium term. We've obviously brought down the 2026 to 10% to 11%. And so you'd imagine there's some movement, at least for the 2026 in terms of those targets, Banking will likely be a little bit lower than the mid-15%, if I think about 2026 as being that medium-term target date. But over time, I expect that the targets that I've set are the targets that we will achieve and even more because, as Jane mentioned, 10% to 11%, while that's our 2026 target, it is not our longer-term target as we think about RoTCE and the strength of these businesses in the aggregate franchise. So hopefully, that answers your question.
speaker: MARK MASON
source:
MARK MASON (CFO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 15

text: And in terms of org simplification, culture, the best is still ahead, that is for sure. The org went through a lot. I'm really proud of how people responded. And I think we're really proud of how each of the lines of business are driving the business performance forward. The bank is simpler. There is tremendous transparency for our investors as well as for me. There's much greater proximity to the businesses now. And you can see that the benefits that we're starting to realize from the strategy as we get closer and closer to the RoTCE targets and beyond for each of the businesses. So I'm pleased to have 2024 behind us. I'm proud of what we achieved in 2024. All the focus is on the future. Onwards.
speaker: JANE FRASER

JANE FRASER (CEO)
Citigroup, Q4, 2024 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 15

Other (Other)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 1

text: April 14, 2023
speaker: Other
source:
Other (Other)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 1

text: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to JPMorgan Chase’s First Quarter 2023 Earnings Call. This call is being recorded.
speaker: Operator
source:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Your line will be muted for the duration of the call. We will now go live to the presentation. Please stand by.
speaker: Operator
source:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: At this time, I would like to turn the call over to JPMorgan Chase's Chairman and CEO, Jamie Dimon, and Chief Financial Officer, Jeremy Barnum.
speaker: Operator
source:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Mr. Barnum, please go ahead.
speaker: Operator
source:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Thanks, and good morning, everyone. The presentation is available on our website, and please refer to the disclaimer on the back.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Starting on page 1, the Firm reported net income of $12.6 billion, EPS of $4.10 on revenue of $39.3 billion and delivered an ROTCE of 23%.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: These results included $868 million of net investment securities losses in Corporate.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Before reviewing our results for the quarter, let's talk about the recent bank failures. Jamie has addressed a number of the important themes in his shareholder letter and a recent televised interview so I will go straight to the specific impacts on the firm.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: As you would expect, we saw significant new account opening activity and meaningful deposit and money market fund inflows, most significantly in the Commercial Bank, Business Banking and AWM.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Regarding the deposit inflows, at the Firmwide level, average deposits were down 3% quarter-on-quarter while end-of-period deposits were up 2% quarter-on-quarter – implying an intra-quarter reversal of the recent outflow trend as a consequence of the March events.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: We estimate that we have retained approximately $50 billion of these deposit inflows at quarter-end.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: It's important to note that while the sequential period-end deposit increase is higher than we would have otherwise expected, our current full year NII outlook – which I will address at the end – still assumes modest deposit outflows from here.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: We expect these outflows to be driven by the same factors as last quarter, as well as the expectation that we will not retain all of this quarter's inflows.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Now back to the quarter, touching on a few highlights.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: We grew our IB fee wallet share, consumer spending remains solid with combined debit and credit card spend up 10% year-on-year, and credit continues to normalize, but actual performance remains strong across the company.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: On page 2, we have some more detail. Revenue of $39.3 billion was up $7.7 billion or 25% year-on-year.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: NII ex. Markets was up $9.2 billion or 78%, driven by higher rates, partially offset by lower deposit balances.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: NIR ex. Markets was down $1.1 billion or 10%, driven by the securities losses previously mentioned as well as lower IB fees and lower auto lease income on lower volume, and Markets revenue was down $371 million or 4% year-on-year.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Expenses of $20.1 billion were up $916 million or 5% year-on-year, driven by compensation-related costs reflecting the annualization of last year's headcount growth and wage inflation.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: These results include the impact of the higher FDIC assessment I mentioned last quarter which, of course, is unrelated to recent events.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: And credit costs of $2.3 billion included net charge-offs of $1.1 billion, predominantly in Card.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: The net reserve build of $1.1 billion was largely driven by deterioration in our weighted-average economic outlook.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: On to balance sheet and capital on page 3. We ended the quarter with a CET1 ratio of 13.8%, up about 60 basis points, which was primarily driven by the benefit of net income less distributions and AOCI gains.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: And in line with what we previously said, we resumed stock buybacks this quarter and distributed a total of $1.9 billion in net repurchases back to shareholders.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Now, let's go to our businesses starting with CCB on page 4.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Touching quickly on the health of U.S. consumers and small businesses based on our data. Both continue to show resilience and remain on the path to normalization, as expected, but we continue to monitor their activity closely.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Spend remains solid and we have not observed any notable pullback throughout the quarter.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Moving to financial results, CCB reported net income of $5.2 billion, on revenue of $16.5 billion, which was up 35% year-on-year.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: In Banking and Wealth Management, revenue was up 67% year-on-year, driven by higher NII on higher rates.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Average deposits were down 2% quarter-on-quarter, in line with recent trends.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Throughout the quarter, we continued to see customer flows to higher yielding products as you would expect, but we're encouraged by what we are capturing in CDs and our wealth management offerings.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Client investment assets were down 1% year-on-year, but up 7% quarter-on-quarter, driven by market performance as well as strong net inflows.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: In Home Lending, revenue was down 38% year-on-year, largely driven by lower net interest income from tighter loan spreads and lower production revenue.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 2

text: Moving to Card Services and Auto – revenue was up 14% year-on-year, largely driven by higher Card Services NII on higher revolving balances, partially offset by lower Auto lease income.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Credit card spend was up 13% year-on-year.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Card outstandings were up 21%, driven by strong new account growth and revolve normalization.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: And in Auto, originations were $9.2 billion, up 10% year-on-year.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Expenses of $8.1 billion were up 5% year-on-year reflecting the impact of wage inflation and higher headcount.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: In terms of credit performance this quarter, credit costs were $1.4 billion, reflecting reserve builds of $300 million in Card and $50 million in Home Lending.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Net charge-offs were $1.1 billion, up about $500 million year-on-year, in line with expectations as delinquency levels continue to normalize across portfolios.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Next, the CIB on page 5. CIB reported net income of $4.4 billion on revenue of $13.6 billion.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Investment Banking revenue of $1.6 billion was down 24% year-on-year.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: IB fees were down 19%. We ranked number one with first quarter wallet share of 8.7%.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: In advisory, fees were down 6% compared to a strong first quarter last year.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Our underwriting businesses continued to be affected by market conditions with fees down 34% for debt and 6% for equity.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: In terms of the outlook, the dynamics remain the same: our pipeline is relatively robust, but conversion is sensitive to market conditions and the economic outlook.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: We expect the second quarter and the rest of the year to remain challenging.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Moving to Markets, total revenue was $8.4 billion, down 4% year-on-year.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Fixed Income was flat. Rates was strong during the rally early in the quarter, as well as through the elevated volatility in March.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Credit was up on the back of higher client flows and Currencies & Emerging Markets was down relative to a very strong first quarter in the prior year.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Equity Markets was down 12%, driven by lower revenues in derivatives relative to a strong first quarter in the prior year and lower client activity in Cash.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Payments revenue was $2.4 billion, up 26% year-on-year.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Excluding the net impact of equity investments, primarily a gain in the prior year, it was up 55%, with the growth driven by higher rates, partially offset by lower deposit balances.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Securities Services revenue of $1.1 billion was up 7% year-on-year, driven by higher rates, partially offset by lower deposit balances and market levels.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Expenses of $7.5 billion were up 2% year-on-year as higher headcount and wage inflation were largely offset by lower revenue-related compensation.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Moving to the Commercial Bank on page 6. Commercial Banking reported net income of $1.3 billion.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Revenue of $3.5 billion was up 46% year-on-year, driven by higher deposit margins.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Payments revenue of $2 billion was up 98% year-on-year driven by higher rates, and gross Investment Banking revenue of $881 million was up 21% year-on-year on increased M&A and bond underwriting from large deal activity.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Expenses of $1.3 billion were up 16% year-on-year, largely driven by higher compensation expense, including front office hiring and technology investments, as well as higher volume-related expense.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Average deposits were down 16% year-on-year and 5% quarter-on-quarter, predominantly driven by continued attrition in non-operating deposits as well as seasonally lower balances.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Loans were up 13% year-on-year and 1% sequentially.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: C&I loans were up 1% quarter-on-quarter, with somewhat different dynamics based on client size.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: In Middle Market Banking, higher rates and recession concerns have decreased new loan demand and utilization, which is also leading to weakness in capex spending.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: In Corporate Client Banking, utilization rates increased modestly quarter-on-quarter as capital market conditions led more clients to opt for bank debt.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: CRE loans were also up 1% sequentially, with higher rates creating headwinds from both originations and prepayments.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: And given the recent focus on commercial real estate, let me remind you that our office sector exposure is less than 10% of our portfolio and is focused in urban dense markets; and nearly two-thirds of our loans are multifamily, primarily in supply constrained markets.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Finally, credit costs of $417 million included a net reserve build of $379 million predominantly driven by what I mentioned upfront.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Then to complete our lines of business, AWM on page 7. Asset & Wealth Management reported net income of $1.4 billion with pre-tax margin of 35%.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Revenue of $4.8 billion was up 11% year-on-year, driven by higher deposit margins on lower balances and a valuation gain on our initial investment triggered by taking full ownership of our Asset Management Joint Venture in China, partially offset by the impact of lower average market levels on management fees and lower performance fees.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Expenses of $3.1 billion were up 8% year-on-year, predominantly driven by compensation, reflecting growth in our private banking advisor teams, higher revenue-related compensation and the run-rate impact of acquisitions.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: For the quarter, net long-term inflows were $47 billion, led by Fixed Income and Equities.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: And in liquidity, we saw net inflows of $93 billion, inclusive of our ongoing deposit migration.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: AUM of $3 trillion was up 2% year-on-year and overall client assets of $4.3 trillion were up 6% driven by continued net inflows into liquidity and long-term products.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: And finally, loans were down 1% quarter-on-quarter, driven by lower securities-based lending, while average deposits were down 5%.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Turning to Corporate on page 8. Corporate reported net income of $244 million.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Revenue was $985 million compared to a net loss of $881 million last year.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: NII was $1.7 billion, up $2.3 billion year-on-year, due to the impact of higher rates.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: NIR was a loss of $755 million compared with a loss of $345 million in the prior year, and included the net investment securities losses I mentioned earlier.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Expenses of $160 million were down $24 million year-on-year.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: And credit costs of $370 million were driven by reserve builds on a couple of single name exposures.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 3

text: Next, the Outlook on page 9. We now expect 2023 NII and NII ex. Markets to be approximately $81 billion.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: This increase in guidance is primarily driven by lower rate paid assumptions across both consumer and wholesale in light of the expectation of Fed cuts later in the year, as well as slightly higher card revolving balances.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Note that in line with my comments at the outset, recent deposit balance increases are not a meaningful contributor to the upward revision in the NII outlook given that we expect a meaningful portion of the recent inflows to reverse later in the year.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: I would point out that this outlook still embeds significant reprice lags: we think a more sustainable NII ex. Markets run-rate in the medium-term is well below this quarter's $84 billion, as well as below the $80 billion that is implied for the rest of the year by our full year guidance; and while we don't know exactly when this lower run-rate will be reached, when it happens, we believe it will be around the mid-70s.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: And, of course, as we mentioned last quarter, this NII outlook remains highly sensitive to the uncertainty associated with the timing and the extent of deposit reprice, investment portfolio decisions, the dynamics of QT and RRP, the trajectory of Fed funds, as well as the broader macroeconomic environment – including its impact on loan growth.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Separately, it's worth noting that Markets NII may start to trend slightly positive towards the end of the year as a function of mix and rate effects.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Moving to expenses, our outlook for 2023 continues to be about $81 billion.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Importantly, this does not currently include the impact of the pending FDIC special assessment.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: And on credit, we continue to expect the 2023 Card net charge-off rate to be approximately 2.6%.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: So to wrap up, our strong results this quarter once again highlight the earnings power of this diversified franchise.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: We have benefited from our fortress principles and commitment to invest, which we will continue to do as we head into an increasingly uncertain environment.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: With that – operator please open the line for Q&A.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Please stand by. The first question is coming from the line of Steve Chubak with Wolfe Research, now open.
speaker: Operator
source:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Hey, good morning.
speaker: Steven Chubak
source:
Steven Chubak (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Good morning, Steve.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: So, Jamie, I was actually hoping to get your perspective on how you see the recent developments with SVB impacting the regulatory landscape for the big banks.
speaker: Steven Chubak
source:
Steven Chubak (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: In your letter you spent a fair amount of time highlighting the consequences of overly stringent capital requirements, the risk of steering more activities to the less regulated nonbanks.
speaker: Steven Chubak
source:
Steven Chubak (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: But what are some of the changes that you're scenario planning for – whether it's higher capital, increase in FDIC assessment fees? And along those same lines, how you're thinking about the buyback given continued strong capital build, but a lot of macro uncertainty at the moment.
speaker: Steven Chubak
source:
Steven Chubak (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Well, I think you were already kind of complete with answering your own question there.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Look, we're hoping that everyone just takes a deep breath and looks at what happened and the breadth and depth of regulations already in place.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Obviously, when something happens like this, you should adjust, think about it.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: So I think down the road there may be some limitations on held-to-maturity, maybe more TLAC for certain type-size banks, and more scrutiny on interest rate exposure, and stuff like that.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: But it doesn't have to be a revamp of the whole system, just recalibrating things the right way.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: And I think it should be done knowing what you want the outcome to be.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: The outcome you should want is very strong community and regional banks.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: And certain actions are taken which are drastic – it could actually make them weaker. So, that's all it is.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: We do expect higher capital from Basel IV, effectively and, obviously there's going to be an FDIC assessment – that'll be what it is.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 4

text: Got it. And just in terms of appetite for the buyback, just given some of the...
speaker: Steven Chubak
source:
Steven Chubak (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: Oh, yeah.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: ...elevated macro uncertainties.
speaker: Steven Chubak
source:
Steven Chubak (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: Well, we've told you that we're kind of penciling in $12 billion for this year.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: Obviously, capital is more than that, but – and we did a little bit of buyback this quarter. We're going to wait and see.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: We don't mind keeping our powder dry, and you've seen us do that with investment portfolios, and we're also going to do that with capital.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: That's great. I'll hop back into the queue. Thanks so much for taking my questions.
speaker: Steven Chubak
source:
Steven Chubak (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: Okay.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: Thank you. The next question comes from the line of Ken Usdin with Jefferies. You may proceed.
speaker: Operator
source:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: Hey, thanks. Good morning. Hey, Jeremy, I was just wondering if you can just give us a little bit more detail on those lower funding expectation points that you made, just in terms of is it because of what you can offer the client that might allow you to kind of keep that beta lower?
speaker: Ken Usdin
source:
Ken Usdin (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: And maybe you can just kind of wrap it into what your overall beta expectations are in that revised update? Thank you.
speaker: Ken Usdin
source:
Ken Usdin (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: Yeah, sure. So let me just summarize the drivers of the change in the outlook.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: So the primary driver really is lower deposit rate paid expectations across both consumer and wholesale, which, as you mentioned, is driven by a couple factors.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: So, the change in the rate environment, with cuts coming sooner in the outlook, all else equal, does take some pressure off the reprice.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: And as you said, we're getting a lot of positive feedback from the field on our product offerings.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: The short-term CD, in particular, is really getting a lot of positive feedback from our folks in the branches. It's been very attractive to yield-seeking customers. So that's kind of working well.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: And then on the asset side, we are seeing a little bit higher Card revolve, which is helping.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: And I'll just remind you that at a conference in February, I suggested that we were already starting to feel like some of the uncertainties we mentioned when giving the guidance had started all moving in the same direction, and that was one of the things that contributed to the upward revision, like all of the uncertainty kind of went the same way.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: But as Jamie's pointed out – those uncertainties are all still there, we highlight them on the page, and as we look forward to this year and to next year and the medium-term we remain very focused on those.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 5

text: Yeah, and as a follow-up on the point about rate expectations coming now in, and potentially getting cut sooner – how do you take a look at what that might mean just for the broader economy?
speaker: Ken Usdin
source:
Ken Usdin (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Do you think it's more just because inflation's coming down? Do you think it's because the Fed's just got to react to an even tougher economy and still some of those storm clouds that might be out there?
speaker: Ken Usdin
source:
Ken Usdin (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Just kind of your general thinking about the other read-throughs of what lower rates quicker will mean for the broader economy.
speaker: Ken Usdin
source:
Ken Usdin (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Well first of all, I don't quite believe it.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: So the Fed has the rate curve, the forward short-term rate curve, almost at 1% higher than what the market has.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: So one of the things you got to always prepare for is – it could be anything, we don't know what the rate curve is going to be in a year. And so we're quite cautious in that and quite thoughtful about that.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Obviously, the short-term read is higher recessionary risk and then inflation coming down.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: So I think inflation will come down a little bit, but it could easily be stickier than people think and therefore, the rate curve will have to go up a little bit.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Okay. Thank you very much.
speaker: Ken Usdin
source:
Ken Usdin (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Thank you. The next question comes from the line of John McDonald with Autonomous Research. You may proceed.
speaker: Operator
source:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Hi, thanks. Jeremy, wanted to follow up again on the drivers of the NII revision and the lower rates paid assumption.
speaker: John McDonald
source:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: You mentioned the Fed cuts coming sooner and positive feedback on the customer offers.
speaker: John McDonald
source:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: What about the March events? Do the bank failures there that happened in March – in your view, do they slow the reprice intensity because folks are moving other than price reasons?
speaker: John McDonald
source:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Or they intensify it industry-wide because smaller banks have to reprice to keep their deposits? How do those events influence your view of the reprice?
speaker: John McDonald
source:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Yeah. John, it's a really good question, and we've obviously thought about that.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: But as we sit here today, I guess I have two answers to that.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: One is it's not meaningfully affecting our current outlook – we don't see it as a major driver.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: And I think in terms of the larger dynamics that you lay out, it's just a little too early to tell. But from where we are right now, the base case is no real impact.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Okay. And then I wanted to ask Jamie – there's a narrative out there that the industry could see a credit crunch – banks are going to stop lending, even Jay Powell mentioned that as a risk.
speaker: John McDonald
source:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Do you see that in terms of anything you look at in terms of lending and is that a reaction that makes sense – that banks might be retrenching a lot here? Do you worry about that for the economy in terms of credit crunch? Thanks.
speaker: John McDonald
source:
John McDonald (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Yeah. I wouldn't use the word credit crunch if I were you.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Obviously, there's going to be a little bit of tightening, and most of that will be around certain real estate things.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: And you've heard it from real estate investors already, so I just look at that as a kind of thumb on the scale.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: It just makes the Fed's conditions be a little bit tighter, it increases the odds of a recession – that's what that is. It's not like a credit crunch.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Thank you. Our next question comes from Erika Najarian with UBS. You may proceed.
speaker: Operator
source:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 6

text: Hi. Good morning. My first question is you mentioned that your reserve build was driven mostly by worse economic assumptions.
speaker: Erika Najarian
source:
Erika Najarian (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: I'm wondering if you could update us on what unemployment rate you're assuming in your reserve.
speaker: Erika Najarian
source:
Erika Najarian (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Yeah. So, Erika, as you know, we take – not going to go into a lot of detail here – but we take the outlook from our economists, we run a bunch of different scenarios and we probability-weight those.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: The central case outlook from our research team hasn't actually changed, but we felt that in line with what Jamie just said in terms of a little bit of tightening as a result of the events of March, it made sense to add a little bit of weight to our relative adverse case.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: So we did that, which changed the weighted-average expectation. And I think that the weighted-average peak unemployment that we're using now is something like 5.8%.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: So, as you think about all of what you've just told us – so $81 billion of NII this year, and who knows when medium-term is going to happen of mid-70s, the clear strength of the franchise producing 23% ROTCE in a quarter where your CET1 is 13.8% and a reserve that already reflects 5.8% unemployment.
speaker: Erika Najarian
source:
Erika Najarian (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: As we think about recession and what JPMorgan can earn in a recession, do you think you can hit 17% ROTCE even in 2024 – assuming we do have a recession in 2024 as everybody is expecting – given all these revenue dynamics and how prepared you are on the reserve?
speaker: Erika Najarian
source:
Erika Najarian (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Yeah. I mean that's an interesting question, Erika. I guess I'll say a couple things.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: It's a great question, so I want to see how Jeremy answers it.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Okay. Let's take a crack. Let's see what the boss thinks.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: I think number one, we believe, have said, and continue to believe that this is fundamentally a 17% through the cycle ROTCE franchise, so number one.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Number two, as Jamie always says, we run this company for all different scenarios and to have it be as resilient as possible across all different scenarios.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: On the particular question of ROTCE expectations in 2024 contingent on the particular economic outlook, obviously it depends a lot on the nature of the recession.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: I think we feel really good about how the company is positioned for a recession, but we're a bank.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: A very serious recession is of course going to be a headwind for returns, but we think even in a fairly severe recession, we'll deliver very good returns – whether that's 17% or not is too much detail for now.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Thank you.
speaker: Erika Najarian
source:
Erika Najarian (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: The next question comes from the line of Jim Mitchell from Seaport Global Securities. You may proceed.
speaker: Operator
source:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 7

text: Hey. Good morning. Maybe just a little bit on the deposit, your thought process there. You've seen some inflows. Why do you think that you lose them going forward?
speaker: Jim Mitchell
source:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: And just maybe talk a little bit about the dynamic in pricing – do you feel like given the inflows, do you see some pricing power for the larger banks?
speaker: Jim Mitchell
source:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Yeah. A couple things there. So, first of all, we don't know. Right? The deposits just came in. We don't know. We're guessing.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Number two, the deposits just came in. So, by definition, these are somewhat flighty deposits because they just came into us, so it's prudent and appropriate for us to assume that they won't be particularly stable.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Number three, there's a natural amount of internal migration of deposits to money funds so you have to overlay that and that's embedded in our assumptions.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: And number four, it's a competitive market, and it's entirely possible that people temporarily come to us and then over time decide to go elsewhere.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: So, for all of those reasons, we're just being realistic about the stickiness of it.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: If I add, I would say, categorically, there's no pricing power that the bigger banks have because if you look at the pricing – and we look at pricing sheets all the time – every bank is in a slightly different position and every bank is competing in three-month, six-month, nine-month savings rates.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: And then you have the online banks, you got treasury bills, you got money market funds. There's no pricing power for the bank, but obviously we all have different franchises and we're all in a slightly different position.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: No, fair – all fair points. And maybe just a follow-up on John's question on the lending environment. You talked about the industry likely pulling back.
speaker: Jim Mitchell
source:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Are you changing your underwriting standards in any way? Just trying to think through is there potential for some market share gains given your strength of capital and liquidity? Or how you're thinking about the loan environment?
speaker: Jim Mitchell
source:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: I'd say very modestly, but we look at that all the time.
speaker: Jamie Dimon
source:
Jamie Dimon (CEO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Yeah. And we always say, right, we underwrite through the cycle.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: And I think notably, we didn't loosen our underwriting standards when all the numbers looked crazy good during the pandemic, and we're not going to overreact now and tighten unreasonably.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Some of that correction happens naturally – credit metrics deteriorate for borrowers whether in consumer or wholesale, and that might make them leave our pre-existing risk appetite, but we're not running around aggressively tightening standards right now.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Okay. Great. Thanks.
speaker: Jim Mitchell
source:
Jim Mitchell (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: The next question comes from the line of Gerard Cassidy with RBC Capital Markets. You may proceed.
speaker: Operator
source:
Operator (Host)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 8

text: Thank you. Hi, Jeremy.
speaker: Gerard Cassidy
source:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Hey, Gerard.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: In your comments about your CET1 ratio, obviously it came in strong at 13.8%.
speaker: Gerard Cassidy
source:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: You've got the GSIB buffer obviously going up next year, and we have the stress test coming this summer or in June – the results – which maybe will lead to banks, including yours, having a higher Stress Capital Buffer. Where should we think about that CET1 ratio being by the end of the year, do you think?
speaker: Gerard Cassidy
source:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Yeah. So a few things on there, Gerard.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: So we have previously said that we were targeting 13.5% in the first quarter of 2024 as a function of assuming an unchanged SCB, the increased GSIB step and operating with a 50-basis-point buffer.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: So, the point that Jamie made a second ago, in light of the environment, Basel IV, dry powder, you know, who knows how we'll tweak that going forward. But that's still our base case assumption.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Specifically on the stress test, contrary to what I've heard some people argue, our ability to predict the SCB ahead of time from running our own process is actually quite limited.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: And you'll remember last year that even though we did predict an increase, we were off by almost a factor of two in terms of how big it wound up being, and that was a big surprise for the whole industry.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: So, we want to be quite humble about our ability to predict the SCB.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: But having said that, for right now we are assuming it will be unchanged. There are some tailwinds in there through the OCI, but we believe there will likely be some offsets and harsher credit shocks in the number, so for planning purposes right now we're assuming flat for SCB, and we'll know soon enough what that actual number is.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: Sure. And then just as a follow-up, if I heard you correctly, can you give us a little more color – I think you mentioned in building the loan loss reserve this quarter you identified some one-off credits?
speaker: Gerard Cassidy
source:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: I don't know if that's how you said it – there's some larger credits. Were they commercial real estate oriented? Were they commercial? Any more color there?
speaker: Gerard Cassidy
source:
Gerard Cassidy (Analyst)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9

text: No, it wasn't commercial real estate. It was just a couple of single name items in the Corporate segment.
speaker: Jeremy Barnum
source:
Jeremy Barnum (CFO)
JPMorgan, Q1, 2023 Earnings Call Transcript, Page 9
